Problem: Things existed before we saw them.  Existence preceeds essence.  Reality shapes our perspective of it.  We see things the way they are because the light bounces true off of our eyes and these signals are translated in our brain.  We are responding to external stimuli.  If I blindfold you and march you off of a cliff, but you never saw the cliff or know about it in any way, shape or form, you will fall regardless of your knowledge.  Your perspective of inky clothy blackness does not allow you to walk to the other side of said cliff.  What you see is not as important as what is there.  There is there even when you turn your head.  We know that as object permanence.  That which exists when we do not see it is still there, or still was there.  If I never met you and nobody could tell me anything about you, do I saw that you don't exist, or do I accept that the universe is larger than the confines of my personal existence?  I'll give you a hint: This thing's bigger than both of us.

I don't understand why this is so complicated. Suppose you have a mathematical model that gives you correct answers. If you just want math so you can do engineering and stuff like that, you're done. That's all you need. If you're a physicist you need a model that actually reflects the underlying reality. That's what the word "physics" means. You need to come up with laws that reflect PHYSICAL reality. Feynman caused a lot of damage here by providing mathematical explanations only but damage started with Newton who never physically assigned his forces. Real scientists need to go back to the foundations so we can have proper physics again.

Someone had to make this video! One has to distinguish between a model for a phenomenon and the phenomenon itself, no matter how accurate the model is. Our models are, however useful, mainly metaphysics and their only value is the calculations we can make with them. If you recall in statistics class they teach null and alternative hypothesis, and sufficient and insufficient evidence. So our "laws of nature" are merely hypotheses that have sufficient evidence in favour of them. This is what underlies modern science, and Feynman made this quite clear in his teachings. But there are other eminent scientists like Dawkins whose apparent militancy amazes me.

I would not associate the "shut up and calculate" paradigm with Feynman, but rather with Bohr; waves of possibility traveling every possible path and interfering with each other to contribute to the possibility of a quantum of energy is something that I can abstractly visualize and meshes nicely with quantum field theory and non-locality if one considers that possibility waves are strictly correlational (do not have a direction in time associated with them) prior to a transfer of energy.

Also, the pilot wave hypothesis cannot account for entanglement, so I would discard that as a coherent general model despite its intuitive realist appeal. Interpretations that hold that the particle is "real" before measurement have a hard time explaining double-slit experiments where the intensity of the light or other particles is less than one particle at a time and yet interference still occurs, unless one redefines the term "particle" to include an entity that can be in multiple places simultaneously, which seems to diverge too much from the original particle concept of a localizable object to still retain the label.
Congratulations,  you finally got the point of doing philosophy!

There could be something to be learned where one model makes a prediction contrary to another model. In the distant past, very complex models were abandoned in favor of simpler models. A few centuries later, those simple models were superseded by more complex ones. It's scientific progress either way.

If two models always produce equally valid predictions, I suppose the two models could eventually be reduced down to one more complete ('elegant') model with a little more insight. Or maybe not necessarily. What is 'elegant', after all?

The difference between the moons of Jupiter and quantum interpretations analogies is that we can easily change our perspective and see a circular(ish) orbit for the moons.

Quantum phenomena seem to have reached an information limit. Bohm waves seem to be unobservable for example. So lacking scientific data to choose between models, what we chose to believe seems based on faith.

Of course, some clever scientist might someday find a way to see behind the information limit curtain, changing this, but today's best data suggests these perspectives are all equally true and equally false.

Excellent video, however I must point out that

1) You forgot an "r" at 1:19 which multiplies the ӫ

2) Also at 1:19, force is a vector.
Considering the 2-D model and the body frame B=(er,eθ,e3)
The equation needs to be F̅ = m( ȑ(er) + wx(wxR) + 2*wxR + rӫ(eθ) )
where w = θ(e3), R=r(er)

Should you have wished to make it a scalar, it should have been written as
F=m*sqrt( ((ȑ(er) + wx(wxR))^2 + (2*wxR + rӫ(eθ))^2 ) )

Really great video otherwise! Keep them up!

Everything observed in nature and transformed into understandable maths is a model. And the person to design that model needs to make sacrifices on accuracy (include minor physical effects or not) and he has to write down what it can explain and what not.
Limitations are things scientists have to deal with every day - and including everything one can think of is certainly not the best thing to do - like writing down 20 digits of a decimal number when your measuring accuracy merely is good enough for six ;)

That was a brilliant video. Exceptional demonstration of how our thoughts and views of reality shape what we perceive in all aspects of it. Understanding that the human mind is fallible and limited to thinking in the pattern it does frees one from the binding limitations of their own fallible mind.

I have often found that when I sit back and listen to experts speak in my own field of expertise, they may not be teaching me anything I didn't already "know", but they most certainly always have different ways of viewing it, that ultimately lead to improving my understanding of the whole.

Great message! It's a great reminder that even the things that we truly believe we understand still rely on some underlying spooky action that can always be seen from a different yet possibly equally valid frame of reference. Here's to challenging out paradigms!

This video is nonsense, and I certainly had expected better from MinutePhysics. It would leave the naive viewer with the impression that there is no way of distinguishing circular motion from oscilating motion when viewed edge-on and the two models are of equal validity. But there is, and the beauty of science is that when confronted with two models of equal explanatory power, it keeps going until a hypothesis and experiment is devised that can settle the matter. On the contrary, the idea that every explanation is just a matter of perspective and should be treated as equally valid and in the extreme, that the truth of the matter can't even be determined, is at the heart of postmodernist thinking, and all the dumbfuckery that spawned from it, such as standpoint theory, postfactualism and indeed post-colonialist "science most fall"-movements

How does the Bohm model account for entanglement? Also, the Schrodinger model can't account for relativity. I think of the three models of QM suggested the Feynmann one genuinely performs better... I understand that the point is that there are many explanations that give the same experimental predictions, but you didn't give any examples of theories that actually did this. A better example (in my opinion) would be the Netwonian, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations of classical mechanics. Each works with a different quantity: Force, Action and Energy respectively, but all provably give the same results. Three ways to think about the same problem that are all as good as each other. Sometimes we use one because it allows us to find the answer more easily, but we can use any and will always arrive at the same answer. I loved the video, and the main message is something I can definitely get behind: Our current models are provably broken and we should accept that they are flawed. I am particularly interested in the Bohm model question; I've spent quite some time discussing it with friends and would really love to know if there's an answer or if it genuinely falls short of Schrodinger's quantum mechanics.

If a model is created empirically then it's insight is garbage. You can make an infinite number of models fit a finite set of data points. From some nice, smooth line to a wonky sinusoidal equation that happens to hit the points. Doesn't mean that it's accurate when perturbed. But a complete model built from mathematically proven equations will provide insight when perturbed. A simple example is the Theory of Relativity. It stuck with proven mathematics, and was thus able to predict things beyond imagination. Truth in==Truth out.

The key, though, is the word "complete." If any single portion is either missing or based on empirical data or assumptions then the entire thing becomes suspect. This is why models in soft sciences, like economics, are usually garbage. Or even hard models that haven't been proven yet, like fluid flow. Since the Navier-Stokes problem hasn't been proven/solves, only shown to be empirically correct given enough iterations, any model that uses it will be off.

Problem becomes that we can't know what we don't know. You can't know if a model is complete, or if there is something yet undiscovered missing from it. Not until mathematically proven, at least. Which is basically impossible for most higher level physics problems. Which is why most things remain in the "theory" category despite being empirically proven over and over for decades.
